user_input: Can you provide an overview of the historical significance of The peace Of Utrecht in relation to the events that followed until The peace Of Versailles?
reference_contexts:
HISTORY OF ENGLAND, from The peace
Of Utrecht to the peace Of Versailles,
1713-17S3. By Lord Mahon. in vols ,
full calfpmarble edge.
reference: The peace Of Utrecht marks a significant period in the history of England, spanning from 1713 to 1783, as documented by Lord Mahon. This treaty played a crucial role in shaping the political landscape of Europe and set the stage for subsequent treaties, including The peace Of Versailles.

reference: The Mayor's proclamation called on citizens to preserve peace and abstain from discussing existing topics, reflecting the political sentiments of the time. This was significant as it occurred during a period when Kentucky was navigating its position in the Civil War, with a strong Union sentiment being expressed. The proclamation aimed to maintain unity among citizens amidst the tensions of the conflict, while Kentucky's resolutions indicated a desire to remain independent within the Union, opposing both coercion and secession.

We congratulate Mr.. Memminger upon the

upon having one 80 well fitted to perform its
duties faithfully and upon sound principles.


SECRETARY OF WAR.


Hon. Leroy Pope Walker is a lawyer Of
Huntsville, Alabama, a native Of that county,
Madison, and about forty-hve years OF age.
He il the eldest son Of the late Mai. Walker,
and one Of a family distinguished for talent
and influence. Two Of bis brothers are Hon
Percy Walker, who recently represented the
Mobile district in Congress, and Hon. judge
Richard W. Walker, Of Florence, chairman Of
the Alabama delegation in the present Con-
federste Congress. Hon. L. P Walker at one
time praetieed law in South Alabama and was
fer several sessions speaker of the house Of
representatives Of the State He has been a
consistent democrat Of the State rights school.
For the last ten yeare be has been located 10
Huntsville, and has the reputation Of being
the leading lawyer, and next to Clay, the lead
ing Democrat Of North Alabama. Careful in
the preparation of his cause, and clear, con
else, logical and eloquent in presenting them
before court, be is said to be an eminently sue
cessful practitioner For the last three years
be has been conspicuous In his denuncfation
Of the free soil heresy Of squatteT sovereignty.
In the Alabama Democratic convention which
took ground against 1t, and sent a delegation
to Charleston tc carry out her instructed op-
position, Gen. Walkers influence was marked
and effective. He was one of the delegation
sent here, and exsrted himself ably in resist |
ing the compromises offered. The result all
know. He has been leader In the cause of
the South, and deserves a good place in the
picture. As a man Of clear head, good iudg-
ment, systematic and laborious in his habits,
with undoubted nerve, spirit, energy and will,
we cannot help thinking he is an excellent
election for the Department Of War at the
present juneture.


SECRETARY OF THE NAVY. al


Hon. John Perkins, IT,, was born in Louis
lana July l, 1919. In 1910 be graduated at
Yale college, and subsequently at the law
school Of Harvard college. He began the
practice Of bis profession in New Orleans
In 1851 be was chosen Judge Of the circuit
court Of Louisiana, which position be he'd un-
til elected to Congress in 1853, where be
advocated State rights Democratic measures.
Since 1853 be has devoted bimself to planting
in his native State. The post of Secretary Of
the Navy to the Confederate States is post
requiring prompt energy and sound practical
judgment. A navy is to be organized, and as |
we have recently had occasion to suggest at
length, the manner Of that organization is Of 1
lasting consequence. Upon the wisdom eXer- i
cised in fitting it 10 the wants Of the South, 1
and that as early as practicable, much proper /
ty and many lives, not to say the confederate 4
character before the world, may depend Mr.. /
Perkins bears a high character, and we trust 4
will prove himself folly equal to the task.

<2-hop>

] ton. II regard to the States which havs now

I cans again and sFain-Yea, scores Of tines
/ Of the disasters they were bringing upon the
country. The way now to diminish fhe extent
/ Of the calamity and make il endurable, is ex-
Z actly The opposite to that indicated BY :" Re-
I publican It is not coercion, but a prompt
/ and liberal arrangement BY treaty, securing re-
I eiprocal advantages, satisfactory and Just to
I both parties. Coercion, or any description Of
I bullying, will only make matters worse. All
/ the pending questions, whether relating to the
I property Of tbe United States within tie new
! Republic, or TO commerce, tunnage duties. post
| Office arrangements, etc, can easily be ADJUST
ed in a general settlement, il only we approach
] A. ~. l.
! rOcal commerce and reciprocal post Office ar
rsngements with Canada-why not wi b ths
new Repubhc2 Pursuing this course, our
! trade with the seeded States would not be
greatly disturbed In short, we can make the
new Republic 2 very useful neighb0r and
friend, or a deadly enemy, Just as we please.
Conquer her We cannot. She is too powerful


and brave for that. And we are glad she is


so. Wewant to see no butchery among breth-


rsn.


() Republican - is doubtless aware that


the Congress of the new republic has uHdnf-


nloHsiv passed an ordinance declaring the navi-


cation Of the Father Of Waters free. No


" tribute . is demanded or desired. The whole


theory Of the new republic, 30 far ss trade


and commerce are concerned, is liberal in the


extreme.


a. Yes; we think they have been wronged.
They may Just as easily be wronEed bv Con-


gress in which they are but lean minority, as


if they were not there at all. TIE only defense


they had against unjust legislation on the part


Of the northern majority, was the Constitution.


That would have been a real defense il it bad


been faithfully adhered to. But so long as


there is a "higher law" (not the Bible, but


mems private judgment or opinisn,) 10 which


all other laws are subject, what are constitu-


tions good for? It was because the cotton


States believed they had no protection in the


Constitution or otherwise, against urconsli-


tutionsl and oppressive legislation by Congress


and individual States, that they determined to


protect themselves.


ID or course the incoming administration


has not despoiled the South Of one Of their


rights as yet, for it is not yet n power. What


il iciH do, we will know when the time comes.


We hope for the best; but under the pressure


which will be sure to come to the a2ministrs-
tion from northern ultraists we dare not be


confident. That wing Of the Republican party


is very powerful, though we hope it is gradual
ly losing ground.


lk.) What chance is there for fhat, so long
Al you exclude the South from the Territories
That Shareholders have as good right there as
non slaveholders, and as good a right TO take
their families with them as non-slaveholders
have to take theirs, is plain to anybody who is
willing to see and besides, It has been de-
clsred 10 be SO By the Supreme Court Of the
United States. II you "foree the negro' out
when the Constitution lets him in, you violate
the Constitution, and trample on the rights Of
the South. We are sure the North would
never consent to be excluded from the common
territories; neither viii the South.
reference: The implications of secession for the Confederation were significant, as it involved the states that had seceded throwing their resources into common stock at the date of the confederation. The states that remained in the Union had no higher interest in the coasts of the seceded states than those states had in the coasts of the Northern or Pacific states. This situation highlighted that all states, regardless of when they joined the Union, had equal rights and that the coasts followed the destiny of the land. The discussion around secession also pointed out that coercion would only worsen the situation, suggesting that a prompt and liberal arrangement by treaty would be more beneficial for both parties. The new republic's approach to trade and commerce was described as liberal, indicating a desire for a cooperative relationship rather than conflict.

reference: The sentiments expressed regarding Canada during the period of confederation highlighted the importance of a prompt and liberal arrangement by treaty to secure reciprocal advantages between the United States and Canada. It emphasized that coercion would only exacerbate tensions and that a cooperative approach could transform Canada into a useful neighbor rather than an enemy. The discussion also pointed out that the new republic's navigation policies were liberal, suggesting a desire for peaceful and beneficial relations with Canada amidst the political turmoil.
